page.title: 07SHEEP FARMING
page.content: The sheep are{sheared}at the beginning of June and the wool sold through the{British Wool Marketing {Board. The lambs are sold at eight months and are used either as breeding animals on other farms or are fattened for meat. The sheep have to be{dipped}to kill flies and other pests that breed in the fleece. This usually takes place a few weeks after shearing in July using a long concrete bath which contains the sheep-dip, into which the sheep are herded and submerged. In recent years the farm has fattened more lambs{on the farm}by producing more fodder crops, hay and silage so that animals can be kept through the winter. The fattened lambs are then sold direct to butchers when they weigh 17 kgs each.
